page.title: 01MENDIP PLATEAU ABOVE CHEDDAR
page.content: The top of Mendip Hills is a bleak, undulating plain, divided up into small/medium sized fields bounded mostly by ancient dry-stone walls. The surface of many fields presents a very rough appearance where old quarry workings have become grassed over. There are some trees - a plantation of Scotts Pines exists and Copper Beech line some roads (plantd on top of the dry-stone walls). Self regenerated Hawthorn trees dot the countryside and are very stunted. Many reflect the windy, exposed nature of the habitat by their lopsided growth. Houses are either old and attached to farms or modern bungalows. The roads are generally straight, but narrow. Part of the land is used as a rifle range, the remaining land is used for animal husbandry (mostly dairy cattle.)
